爆头摄影的 3 个便捷灯光设置首先出现在数码摄影学校。它的作者是丹尼斯·德伦纳。

如果您想进入爆头摄影行业，或者您想完善和扩展您的产品组合以使其对潜在客户更具吸引力，那么您必须能够复制几种基本的照明设置。

您不必是灯光奇才，也不必了解数十种复杂的工作室模式。但一些基本设置可以发挥很大作用；他们将使您的头像图像看起来精致而专业，并且还将确保您有几种不同的选择，让您的客户看起来最好。

我在华盛顿特区拍摄了很多公司和演员的头像，我想分享一些我在自己的工作中反复使用的简单但有效的照明设置。请随意复制我建议的爆头照明设置并使用它们来改善您的照片！

1. 一光奇迹

我的标准爆头照明设置使用单一光源：一个位于拍摄对象左侧或右侧的大型漫射闪光灯。我还在脸部下方添加了一个反射器，并在主光源对面添加了另一个反射器。我每年使用这个简单的设置拍摄数百张爆头照片。

我喜欢在我的工作室中使用带有大型八角盒的 Paul C. Buff Einstein 装置，但专用闪光灯和八角盒可能很昂贵。你可以很容易地用一个廉价的热靴灯、一把雨伞和几个 20 美元的反光镜来组装类似的东西。

你可以在下面的照片中看到这个设置，我可怜的妻子凯伦站在其中作为主题。她刚下楼去泡茶，就被伏击了！

调整角度并添加反射器

一旦我的主题就位，我喜欢做一些调整。首先，我调整光源，使其略高于拍摄对象的眼睛水平。对于大多数人来说，我认为最好让光线从上方照射，这样可以在下巴下方投射出微妙的阴影（这会突出下巴并有助于隐藏双下巴）。

然后我调整拍摄对象脸部下方的反光板，并将其调至大约胸部中部的高度。这个反光镜有助于填充脸上的阴影，并为眼睛增添非常漂亮的额外光线。一些爆头摄影师更喜欢使用第二个光源而不是胸部中部的反光镜，但我发现反光镜的设置要简单得多，而且几乎不可能错误使用。

为什么反光板如此万无一失？如果你在拍摄对象下方有另一个灯而不是反光板，并且你不小心压倒了它（因此它比主灯更强大），你最终会得到一些可怕的弗兰肯斯坦照明！使用反射器根本不可能做到这一点 - 基本物理学规定光的反射强度永远不能大于或等于原始光的强度 - 这可以使您避免犯下代价高昂的错误。

最后，我确保在光源对面添加反射器。在上面我工作室的图片中，您可以看到裸露的反射面板，但有时我确实喜欢通过添加较小的黑色面板来淡化这一点，在脸部的那一侧创建较暗的阴影。请注意这里的便携式面板，将其黑色一侧面向我的妻子：

这种效果非常显着，并且还有瘦脸的额外好处。缺点是，如果你的拍摄对象有很多皱纹，你就无法用那一侧的光线来填充这些皱纹。所以它并不适合所有人。

这是一个爆头示例，我使用此效果创建了一个漂亮的戏剧性边缘：

但是，如果您尝试较暗的面板，但它不适合您的拍摄对象，请不要害怕将其拿走并使用纯白色反光板。

一些额外的调整以获得更好的单灯爆头照片

通过这个简单的设置，可以很容易地进行调整并查看最适合特定人脸的效果。通常我会将基本设置保留在黑色反射器上，但有几次我可能会进行更改：

  • 拍摄对象有双下巴，所以我真的很想定义下巴。在这种情况下，我可以将灯光调得特别高，以在下巴下方投射更多阴影（确保我不会调得太高而失去聚光灯），和/或降低或移除下巴下方的反光板。
  • 对象有一头又长又黑的头发。在这种情况下，深色反射器是不必要的，因为我们已经有了头发的深色边缘。相反，我会在侧面使用白色反光镜，或者从后面引入发灯（下一节将详细介绍！）。
  • 拍摄对象有一双深陷的眼睛。我们想要向这些插座发射更多的光，否则我们可怜的拍摄对象最终会看起来像连环杀手或穴居人！在这种情况下，我可能会降低灯光，使其处于视线水平。

在下面的照片中，您可以在阴影侧看到拍摄对象头发的很多细节。那是因为我把我的大白色反光镜拉近了。

2.两灯爆头

您可以使用一灯系统来经营整个爆头业务，但如果您像我一样，您会感到无聊并喜欢尝试新事物。那么让我们引入第二个观点。

对我来说，第二盏灯通常是“踢球灯”（也称为边缘灯或强调灯），来自主灯后面并与主灯相对。我用它来突出下巴，特别是对于男性来说，或者在为女性拍摄头像时突出头发。它特别适合在深色头发上打造一点亮点。

在下面的照片中，我需要一种方法将这个年轻人与黑暗背景分开。我的踢灯成功了！

在我的工作室中，我使用带有条盒的闪光灯来实现此目的，但您也可以使用带有网格的裸闪光灯，甚至是旧的热靴灯，上面贴有纸巾卷，以制作简单的束光筒。重要的是您要控制光线，以免光线射入镜头并产生眩光或缺乏对比度。

3. 三光或四光爆头

我使用三号灯和四号灯来创建干净的白色背景。如果您只有三盏灯，您可以将第三盏灯放在拍摄对象的后面，然后将其照亮背景；如果您拥有四个灯，则可以将第三个和第四个灯放置在拍摄对象的两侧，然后将它们一起射向背景。

白色背景是我最近最喜欢的外观，这有很多原因。我认为它看起来超级明亮、现代、快乐。它在 LinkedIn 和其他在线个人资料中也很流行。

如果您要为公司拍摄企业头像，这也是一个不错的选择，因为它很容易复制并在每次拍摄时获得一致的外观。当您的客户希望为所有员工拍摄相似的头像，而您无法在同一天完成所有头像时，这可能是一件大事。

例如，如果您进行初始拍摄，并且公司要求您在几个月后拍摄新员工，那么复制白色背景效果将比尝试使背景颜色和亮度恰到好处容易得多。

白色背景方法还使您或其他摄影师可以轻松地在全国各地拍摄时保持相同的外观。

无论如何，使用一盏灯还是两盏灯作为背景取决于您的预算和工作空间。

两盏灯可以为您提供更大、更均匀的光线，而一盏灯可能会在边缘周围产生一些衰减（即黑暗），您需要在后期制作中清理这些衰减。所以我通常坚持使用两盏灯。然而，两盏灯也会占用更多空间，所以如果我在某个地方拍摄并且空间紧张，我会切换到一盏。

为您的客户制作一些漂亮的头像！

我希望这篇文章对您有所帮助！创建专业的头像并不一定很困难；正如我所说，通过一些简单的照明设置，您几乎可以满足任何客户的需求。

如果您无法承担使用多个光源的费用，那么单个热靴灯和几个反光板可以创造奇迹！

因此，花一些时间重新创建我上面分享的设置。然后用它们为您的客户制作一些令人惊叹的头像！

如何通过铁丝网拍照（7个有效技巧）的帖子首先出现在数码摄影学校上。它的作者是达伦·罗斯。

如果您遇到一个被铁丝网包围的有趣主题，那么获得好的拍摄效果可能会非常痛苦。这是动物园最常面临的挑战，但我在宠物店拍摄以及拍摄老建筑时也遇到过类似的问题（这些建筑有漂亮的外墙，但周围有铁丝网）。

真的，你永远不知道什么时候你可能需要穿过铁丝网进行拍摄，你会发现自己在最意想不到的情况下挣扎（例如，我最近在蹦床上拍摄了一些孩子，周围有网）。

现在，您不能总是从构图中完全消除栅栏，具体取决于栅栏线的尺寸、线间隙的大小、到拍摄对象的距离以及您的设备。然而，总有一些方法可以最大程度地减少围栏的影响，即使看起来并非如此，而且也有一些方法可以接近围栏内的拍摄对象，以便您可以更轻松地集中注意力。

那么如何穿过铁丝网拍出好看的照片呢？以下是我的一些最佳建议：

1.切换为手动对焦

当您穿过任何类型的栅栏进行拍摄时，尤其是当材料特别明显或距离镜头有些远时，您的相机可能不知道要聚焦在什么上 - 栅栏或其后面的物体。

如果切换到手动对焦模式，您将完全控制焦点内和焦点外的内容，并且可以仔细设置焦点平面，使主要拍摄对象看起来清晰。

2.靠近栅栏

从图像中消除栅栏的最佳方法是使栅栏失焦以致难以察觉。

一种策略是站得非常靠近栅栏——离栅栏太近，以至于栅栏线变得模糊不清。

可能无法直接靠在栅栏上（例如，当您在动物园射杀狮子时，您可能会遇到其他为了自身安全而设置的障碍物），但越近越好。

3.使用大光圈

靠近栅栏会导致其模糊，但如果您可以尽可能扩大镜头光圈（到 f/4、f/2.8，甚至 f/1.4）， 景深就会变窄，并且电线将变得更加失焦。

请注意，焦距越长，景深越浅。因此，如果您使用长焦镜头并以 f/2.8 光圈拍摄，栅栏会比使用广角镜头以 f/2.8 拍摄时更模糊。

4. 等待拍摄对象远离栅栏

当您拍摄用栅栏围起来的建筑物或风景时，这不会有帮助，但如果您的拍摄对象在栅栏后面移动（例如动物园里的猴子），请等到它们稍远一点后再拍摄。

它们距离栅栏越近，栅栏就越清晰，但它们离得越远，栅栏就越模糊（假设您的拍摄对象清晰对焦！）。

5. 调整镜头位置以通过更大的间隙进行拍摄

这不是火箭科学，但考虑栅栏间隙的大小很重要。如果开口很大，最好将这些间隙放置在框架的中间。

它还可以帮助检查栅栏上是否有任何可能有较大间隙的区域，然后调整您的位置，以便将这些区域包含在您的镜头中。 （当然，如果会危及安全，请不要这样做；目标是获得清晰的镜头，而不是以危险的方式接近拍摄对象。）

6.避免电线上的反光和高光

如果您在阳光明媚的日子穿过相对反光的栅栏进行拍摄，您可能会注意到太阳的反射。 （假设周围有明亮的路灯或汽车前灯，在夜间拍摄金属栅栏时也会发生这种情况。）

即使您设法相当有效地模糊了栅栏金属，这些反射也可能非常明显。因此，尝试找到栅栏被遮挡的部分，或者改变相机角度直到反射消失。 （另一种选择是让某人以在栅栏上投下阴影的方式站立！）

7.将栅栏融入你的构图中

您并不总是需要消除镜头中的栅栏。有时我喜欢在我的构图中加入焦点清晰的栅栏，所以如果你很难穿过栅栏进行拍摄，为什么不尝试创造性地使用它呢？

例如，您可以让栅栏线创建有趣的引导线，或者您可以后退几步并捕捉栅栏和您的拍摄对象。栅栏并不总是导致糟糕的摄影！

穿过一些栅栏去拍照！

栅栏通常看起来是一个巨大的摄影问题。然而，我自己已经冲破了很多栅栏，我向你保证它们并不像你想象的那么糟糕。

只需采取措施模糊栅栏，使其不可见即可。如果您无法模糊栅栏，请尝试使用它来创建更强大的照片。

因此，下次您遇到栅栏时，请记住我分享的技巧，看看您是否可以得到一些好的照片！

这篇文章将彻底改变您的摄影的 iPhone 应用程序：Snap Pro 相机首先出现在Digital Photography School上。它由Jaymes Dempsey撰写。

让我们面对现实吧：随身携带一台“严肃”的相机可能会非常不方便。单反相机，甚至更紧凑的无反光镜型号，体积大、笨重且引人注目。 （如果您曾经尝试过将专用的相机带到度假中，甚至只是在一日游中，您将确切知道我在说什么。）

一种解决方案是使用口袋里的相机：智能手机。智能手机摄像头有很多好处；它不仅可以随时使用，而且非常谨慎，与编辑应用程序无缝集成，并拍摄出令人惊讶的高质量照片。

但是，即使是最新，最出色的智能手机摄像机也有限，对于希望捕捉引人注目的，值得投资组合的图像的摄影师，这可能是一个交易的人。考虑一下本机 iPhone 相机应用程序：当然，它可以让您调整一些基本设置，并且根据您的 iPhone 型号，它提供对各种镜头和滤镜的访问，但以下是它不提供的功能：

  • 手动对焦
  • 快门速度调整
  • ISO调整
  • 白平衡调整
  • RAW捕获（此功能已添加到某些iPhone Pro型号中，但在大多数iPhone上仍然不可用）

换句话说，iPhone 原生相机应用程序并不能让您做所有作为追求一流图像的热情摄影师几乎肯定应该做的事情。幸运的是，如果您喜欢 iPhone 摄影的便利性，但又想手动控制相机，那么您还有另一种选择：您可以放弃 iPhone 的本机相机软件，转而使用第三方相机应用程序，这种应用程序可以让您充分发挥自己的能力。 iPhone 摄影师的潜力。

这就是MIOPS的Snap Pro Camera应用程序的来源。

Snap Pro 相机让您可以像 DSLR 一样控制 iPhone 的相机，此外，它还拥有一系列令人惊叹的创意摄影模式，例如运动模糊、光迹、人群去除等。它也非常直观；即使您以前从未使用过手动摄像头应用程序，我怀疑它会花费您超过五分钟的时间来学习界面。 （我花了十分钟，只是因为我在尝试长曝光模式时获得了太多乐趣！）

底线：

无论您是希望用 iPhone 捕捉精彩照片的摄影爱好者，还是希望将 iPhone 变成功能齐全的相机的专业摄影师，Snap Pro Camera 都是您不容错过的应用程序。下面，我将仔细研究 Snap Pro Camera 的独特功能，以便您了解 MIOPS 应用程序的真正革命性 - 以及为什么它是您唯一需要的相机应用程序！

如何开始使用 Snap Pro 相机

Snap Pro 相机易于使用，即使对于初学者来说也是如此。您首先从 App Store 下载应用程序；然后，一旦启动并运行，您将看到这个时尚的界面：

与本机 iPhone 相机应用程序一样，您只需点击图像预览窗口即可设置焦点。您还可以通过向上或向下滑动来更改图像曝光。

在屏幕底部，您会看到快门按钮（如果您愿意，您可以继续点击它来拍摄您的第一张照片！）。快门按钮左侧是图库，您可以在其中访问已拍摄的图像。还有一个图标指示您的相机正在使用的曝光模式。默认情况下，曝光模式设置为 A（或自动），但您可以将其切换为 M（或手动），正如我在下一节中讨论的那样。

在快门按钮的右侧，您可以通过敲击框架图标来访问高级曝光和组成工具：

通过点击滤镜图标，您可以访问一些很酷的滤镜 - 例如 Chrome、Noir 和 Sepia Tone - 让您可以拍摄具有不同创意效果的照片。 （注意：当您选择滤镜时，它不仅会在按下快门按钮后应用于图像文件；它还会应用于图像预览，因此您可以提前看到滤镜将如何影响您的照片！）

在快门按钮上方，您会发现一排相机设置，我将在下一节中详细介绍。 （如果不可见图标，则需要按“快门”按钮旁边的曝光模式图标。）

您还应该看到一些标准的摄像头控件：要在不同焦距之间切换的按钮，以及在后方和前面摄像头之间切换的按钮：

最后，在屏幕顶部，您将看到另一行选项。在左侧，您可以调整拍摄模式：

正是在这里，在这个拍摄模式菜单中，发生了很多有趣的事情。默认情况下，Snap Pro Camera 设置为照片模式，适合一般摄影。但是，该应用程序还提供了用于创意和低光摄影，时间段摄影甚至倾斜偏移视频的模式。

现在，当您在不同的拍摄模式之间切换时，屏幕顶部的设置选项将会发生变化。选择照片模式后，您可以调整相机的纵横比、文件格式和连拍设置：

但是，例如，如果切换到光迹模式，则会出现曝光长度设置：

就是这样——很简单，对吧？您可以根据需要调整设置和切换模式，但一旦熟悉了主菜单和图标，就可以轻松利用该应用程序的领先功能。

在接下来的几节中，我将解释如何使用特定模式和设置来实现惊人的结果。

Snap Pro 相机令人印象深刻的手动控制

如果您想捕获值得投资组合的iPhone照片，则需要控制相机曝光设置。幸运的是，这是Snap Pro摄像机发光的领域之一。

默认情况下，曝光模式将设置为自动，您将看到一个 A：

然而，点击 A，曝光模式将切换为手动。启用手动模式后，您可以点击快门按钮上方的一排图标进行调整：

  • 快门速度
  • ISO
  • 白平衡
  • 焦点

换句话说，您不必让 iPhone 为您做出所有设置决定（这通常会导致图像模糊、有颗粒感或因色偏而损坏），您可以自己做出这些决定，并获得更好得多的结果。

如果您熟悉标准相机设置，您就会知道这是多么革命性的。但如果您以前没有使用过手动控制，在以下几种情况下您可以独立调整 iPhone 的相机设置以获得您想要的照片类型：

  1. 如果您要拍摄动作，可以手动将快门速度提高到 1/500 秒或以上。这样，即使拍摄对象在运动，您也可以确保拍摄对象保持清晰。
  2. 如果您在弱光下拍摄风景、城市景观或建筑，您可以将 iPhone 放在三脚架上，将 ISO 设置为其基本值，然后选择可提供良好曝光的慢速快门速度。这样，您的照片就会包含大量细节 - 但您不必担心高 ISO 噪点会毁掉您的文件。
  3. 如果您拍摄小物体，例如花朵、昆虫，甚至沙粒，您可以近距离拍摄，然后使用手动对焦滑块仔细选择理想的焦点。 （为什么这是必要的？在高倍率下工作时，您的 iPhone 的自动对焦功能会变差，并且您将很难捕捉清晰的照片 - 除非您可以使用手动对焦工具！）
  4. 如果您正在拍摄肖像，但发现图像看起来不自然的黄色或蓝色，您可以手动调整白平衡设置，直到颜色准确为止。

这些类似 DSLR 的控件为严肃摄影提供了巨大的潜力。您不再需要依靠 iPhone 来确定每张照片的“正确”设置；最终，您可以自由进行一贯出色图像所需的调整。

（另外，如果您同时使用 iPhone 和专用相机，您可以来回切换而不会错过任何一个节拍，因为设置非常相似！）

Snap Pro Camera的复杂手动控件不止于此。正如我上面提到的，该应用程序提供高级曝光和构图控制，您可以：

  • 打开构图网格，包括金三角叠加，以帮助改善您的取景
  • 激活倾斜计以确保您的图像始终水平（如果您喜欢拍摄风景或城市景观，这是一件大事！）
  • 打开直方图叠加，这样您就可以始终避免曝光过度或曝光不足

您甚至可以使用斑马条纹功能，该功能会在图像的曝光过度和曝光不足的区域上叠加红色和蓝色条纹：

以及峰值对焦功能，可通过勾勒出画面中清晰的部分来帮助您始终保持焦点：

如果我没有提到新的 RAW 照片拍摄模式，那就是我的失职了，该模式允许您以 RAW 格式而不是 HEIF 或 JPG 格式进行拍摄。 RAW 文件包含的图像数据比 HEIF 和 JPG 文件多得多，因此，您可以使用 RAW 编辑应用程序来恢复曝光过度的高光、恢复曝光不足的阴影、调整颜色以获得艺术效果等。

大多数这些功能在 iPhone 原生相机应用程序中都找不到。但下载 Snap Pro Camera，您就可以访问所有这些设置 – 使您的 iPhone 照片比以前更清晰、构图更佳、曝光更佳。

Snap Pro 相机令人惊叹的长时间曝光拍摄模式

Snap Pro Camera 的手动控制非常出色，对于任何希望拍摄高质量照片的人来说，这无疑使该应用程序值得下载。

但是，正是创造性的拍摄模式将应用程序提升到一个全新的水平。

现在，我没有足够的空间来深入研究每一种拍摄模式——这需要一整本书！ – 但我确实想花一些时间探索我最喜欢的两个：运动模糊和光迹。

运动模糊模式

如何充分利用相机包的帖子首先出现在数码摄影学校上。它的作者是里克·伯克。

作为一名经常旅行的摄影师，我最大的追求不是寻找完美的镜头，而是寻找完美的相机包。如果您曾经购买过相机包（或两个或十个），那么我猜您知道我在说什么。

对于我拥有的每一个包或背包，内部隔板似乎都不适合我的装备。它们创建的隔间要么太小而无法容纳我的镜头，要么太大以至于我的镜头不断移动。结果往往是包里浪费了很多空间，装备也不是完全安全，而且对于留下哪些镜头也做出了痛苦的决定。

现在，我确实有很多装备；旅行时，我一般喜欢携带全画幅相机机身、闪光灯、一套4×5玻璃滤镜、14-24mm镜头、16-35mm镜头、24-120mm镜头、80-400mm镜头镜头、105mm 微距镜头和 24mm f/1.4 镜头。 （是的，我知道有冗余，但每个镜头都有明确的目的！）

根据您喜欢的摄影类型，您可能不会携带那么多。然而，包装不好的相机包仍然是您可能而且很可能会面临的一个问题。

那么解决办法是什么呢？下面，我将解释优化相机包空间的方法，并提供更有效地打包相机包的分步过程。

解释了我有效打包相机装备的简单方法

当我第一次尝试弄清楚如何有效地打包我的相机包时，我认为解决方案可能是去掉分隔物，因为它们似乎是导致我大部分（或全部？）问题的原因。

当然，我不能只拆掉隔板，让我的装备滚动。我需要一种方法来垫我的设备——袋子会被晃来晃去、放下、拿起、撞到。齿轮在其内部移动，如果没有填充物，它最终会受到损坏。

我尝试用包裹来填充我珍贵的相机和镜头的一种选择。有几个品牌专门为相机设备生产包装袋；它们有不同的尺寸，以适应不同的设备。这是我的一个相机包 - ThinkTank Airport 型号- 完全拆除了隔板并添加了包裹：

然而问题是，当我去重新包装我的相机和镜头时，花了太多时间。如果您是一名仅使用一两个主镜头的摄影师，您不经常切换设备，和/或您在节奏较慢的环境中工作，也许它可以工作，但它不适合我。另外，我不喜欢我尝试过的包装，所以我最终又回到了隔板。

几年过去了，我不情愿地继续使用我的隔板。但我最近去了几次旅行，但无法正确配置分隔板，我不得不选择一些东西留下。通常，这意味着没有我认为不需要的镜头——但最终，我总是希望我带了镜头。正如你可能想象的那样，这很糟糕。

最终，我受够了。我去了当地的相机店，再次考虑了这个问题。这一次，我发现自己盯着氯丁橡胶镜片袋。氯丁橡胶袋提供填充物，并且有各种尺寸以适应我套件中的每个镜头，但它们不太紧贴，也不是太大。

我摆弄了袋子，发现我可以将袋子中的镜头和相机相互放置。氯丁橡胶通常为 4-5 毫米厚，​​因此并排的两个袋子的厚度与尼龙搭扣分隔件的厚度大致相同，因此可以提供足够的支撑。

所以我买了足够的氯丁橡胶袋，然后把所有的尼龙搭扣隔板从背包里拿出来。从那时起，我发现我可以很好地适应所有东西，包括我的 80-400mm 镜头。

然而，我确实注意到，在徒步旅行时背上背包后，我的装备并不总是保持在原位——物品往往会沉到底部，这使得当我打开背包时很难找到东西。我戴上了解决问题的帽子，回到了绘图板上，终于解决了一个非常效果的混合解决方案。

在背包的底部，我放置了 80-400mm 镜头（没有袋子）。然后，我添加了一个全宽的分隔器，该分隔器跨过背包的长度，以保护80-400mm的镜头。

接下来，我在氯丁橡胶袋中添加三个镜片。除此之外，我添加了第二个全宽分隔板，这为我留下了一个大隔间，用于存放剩余的镜头（在氯丁橡胶袋中），以及我的滤镜和一些较小的配件，例如镜头布。在大隔间的一侧，我使用一个较小的尼龙搭扣隔板来放置我的相机。

这是整个设置的实际操作：

我知道您可能没有与我相同的装备。但我认为这种通用方法——使用一些但不是全部相机包的隔板，并将任何相邻的镜头放在氯丁橡胶袋中——可以适用于很多人。

如果您认为我的方法可以使您受益，我建议您如何配置和打包相机包：

如何优化您的相机背包

使用这种方法打包整个装备包非常简单。这是四步过程：

  1. 首先，确定哪些镜片要存放在氯丁橡胶袋中以及哪些镜片要放在自己的隔间中。这取决于您拥有的设备，但较短和中等尺寸的镜头非常适合放入袋子中，而最长的镜头可能可以放入自己的隔间中。
  2. 其次，测量您计划存放在袋子中的每个镜片，然后订购袋子。您需要确保袋子内部比镜头大大约半英寸。 （我使用LensCoat 镜头袋。）这些镜头袋的美妙之处在于，如果我决定从包中取出镜头，它仍然可以免受碰撞和跌落的影响。
  3. 第三，考虑您的相机是否需要氯丁橡胶袋。根据您如何安排事情，这可能是必要的。 （我将镜头涂层袋袋用于相机）。选择最适合您相机的一款。
  4. 最后，除去相机袋中的所有全宽度分隔线外，要用长镜头或多个较短的镜头（带有袋子）来填充全宽室。考虑在哪里可以安装配件，如果遇到空间问题，您可以随时移除额外的隔板或根据需要添加部分隔板。

顺便说一句：我从工艺品商店购买了一支银色记号笔和一些模板，在每个袋子的外部贴上标签，以便于识别。当您需要快速找到特定镜头并且不想浪费时间在不同的袋子中寻找时，这会很有帮助。

现在轮到您配置相机背包了！

包装我的相机包的方法产生了巨大的不同，我强烈建议您自己尝试。

即使我拥有所有必需的装备，我发现如果需要的话我可以在相机包中放入更多东西，仅仅是因为我不受分隔板允许我做的事情的限制。它仍然不是我认识的每个摄影师都在寻找的永远难以捉摸的“完美相机包”，但对我来说，它只是更接近了一点。

本文于 Anne McKinnell 和 Jaymes Dempsey 的贡献下于 2024 年 4 月更新。

“为什么我的照片模糊？”这是一个常见的问题，尤其是对于第一次探索摄影的人来说。不幸的是，它没有一个简单的答案。

事实上，照片模糊是由多种因素造成的，因此，如果您的照片模糊，通常很难查明确切的问题。您是否使用了不正确的手持技术？您的镜头有缺陷吗？您是否选择了错误的快门速度？这样的例子还在继续。因此，对于大多数摄影师来说，使文件始终保持清晰是一个遥不可及的目标。

但是，虽然照片模糊问题没有一个万能的解决方案，但导致图像模糊的常见原因有很多，每种原因都有自己的简单解决方法。

这就是我写这篇文章的原因。下面，我列出了您可能拍摄出模糊照片的 10 个主要原因，虽然其中一些您可能很熟悉，但其他一些可能会让您感到惊讶。

因此，如果您正在努力拍摄清晰的照片，这是我的建议：

仔细检查清单。不要跳过任何部分，并确保避免我讨论的常见错误和陷阱。一旦遇到可能给您带来问题的项目，请尽一切努力将其从工作流程中删除——无论这意味着给自己写一张纸条放在相机包中，还是更改相机菜单中的默认设置，或投资新装备。

我们都讨厌观看一张图像时却发现它很模糊的感觉。但如果您使用此列表并进行必要的更改，我保证您的照片将比以往更加清晰。

1.你的快门速度太慢

对于任何手持相机的人来说，过慢的快门速度是照片模糊的头号罪魁祸首。

快门速度越慢，相机的振动（通常是由手和手臂的微小运动引起）就越有可能产生模糊。这是我一直看到的一个问题，并且您常常没有意识到它正在困扰您的工作流程，直到有人向您指出为止。

您可能认为您可以保持相机完全静止半秒钟，但我向您保证：世界上很少有人能做到这一点。大多数人只能手持 1/160 秒到 1/80 秒范围内的相机，因此，如果您使用低于1/80 秒的快门速度，则很可能会出现模糊。

事实上，即使您的快门速度快于 1/80 秒，并且即使您使用了良好的手持技术（见下文！），由于相机抖动而导致的模糊仍然会逐渐出现。这是因为最慢的快门速度您可以有效手持相机的方式取决于镜头的焦距、镜头的尺寸和放大倍率。

那么如何确保快门速度足够快以防止模糊呢？

从这个经验法则开始：

您的快门速度应该是镜头焦距的倒数。

因此，如果您使用的是60mm镜头，则快门速度应为1/60或更快。对于 200mm 镜头，至少使用 1/200s。使用400mm镜头，使用至少1/400。

（镜头长度越长，相机抖动放大得越多，因此长焦镜头需要更快的快门速度。）

现在，虽然互惠规则是一个有用的起点，但您应该在一些特定场景中对其进行修改。

首先，如果您以高倍率拍摄，您需要将快门速度提高到比倒数规则建议的速度高一些。因此，如果您要用100mm宏观镜头拍摄花瓣，则理想情况下应使用1/160的快门速度来保持图像的清晰度。如果您将微距镜头推至其绝对最大放大倍数，您将需要进一步提高快门速度。当我以1：1宏伟的方式拍摄花朵时，我发现我通常需要大约1/200来防止图像模糊（并且在可能的情况下，我会以1/250或什至1/320的安全性拍摄才能安全） 。

Second, if you're photographing action, such as a person running across a field, your shutter speed will need to be far faster than the reciprocal rule suggests.快速移动的拍摄对象需要 1/500 秒、1/1000 秒的快门速度，或者在处理超快的拍摄对象（例如飞行中的鸟类）时，需要 1/2000 秒及以上。

第三，一些镜头和相机内置了图像稳定技术。 Image stabilization usually allows you to slow your minimum shutter speed by around 3-5 stops, so if your equipment includes this technology, and you know that its image-stabilization features are active, you can often handhold a few stops slower than the reciprocal rule建议。 But you should always be cautious, and if you haven't tested your equipment's capabilities, I recommend taking a few extra shots just to be sure you end up with a usable image.

您的最低快门速度是多少？

除了倒数规则之外，了解您自己的个人最低快门速度也很重要。

你看，我们都有点颤抖，但我们中的一些人比其他人颤抖得更多。因此，最好了解一下相机抖动在什么情况下会成为您的问题。

尝试这个练习（为了获得最佳效果，请尝试使用您拥有的每个镜头！）：

将相机设置为快门优先模式并以 1/500 秒的速度拍摄照片。然后降低快门速度并拍摄另一张图像。继续此操作，直到时间一直降至 1 秒左右，然后在计算机上调出图像。问问自己：模糊什么时候会成为问题？ I rarely go below 1/125s if I'm handholding my camera, even if I'm using a shorter lens.我发现在较慢的快门速度下我无法始终保持图像清晰，而且我只是不想冒拍摄模糊的风险。

2.您没有使用三脚架

需要明确的是，您并不总是需要三脚架来拍摄清晰的照片。如果您遵循我上面列出的指南，您可以避免由于相机抖动而导致的模糊，并且您的手持照片将看起来清晰。

然而，有时使用足够快的快门速度并不可取——要么是因为没有足够的光线，要么是因为你故意模糊画面中的某些东西。

在这些情况下，互惠规则变得毫无价值。但是，您不需要手持相机并希望得到最好的结果，而是需要通过其他方式保持相机稳定来防止相机抖动导致的模糊。

The best option, and the one that I highly recommend, is using a tripod .即使您将快门速度调至一秒或更长，它也能让您的相机保持完全稳定。只要您的三脚架坚固，您就可以使用持续几分钟甚至几小时的快门速度来拍摄照片（尽管如果您确实拍摄了几个小时，则需要注意其他问题，例如风和文件噪音）。

如果三脚架太不方便，请考虑使用独脚架，这是一种更紧凑、更灵活的选择（尽管它无法提供接近相同水平的支撑，因此如果将快门速度降至 1 以下，则需要小心） /20 秒左右）。

Also, when you use a tripod, image stabilization is not necessary and may even be counterproductive, so it's a good idea to get in the habit of turning any IS off when you put your camera on a tripod.

3.你的持相机技术很差

如果您手持相机，并且确信自己使用了足够快的快门速度，但文件仍然模糊，那么是时候考虑您的手持技术了。糟糕的技术可能会导致相机额外抖动，从而导致模糊。

为了获得最佳稳定性，请练习官方摄影师位置：

双脚稍微分开站立，一只脚向前摇晃，并牢固地踩住，以稳定身体从右到左、从后到前。用左手从下方握住镜头支撑相机，用右手抓住手柄并轻轻按下快门按钮。将肘部紧贴胸部，并使用取景器而不是实时取景屏幕（将相机靠近脸部有助于保持稳定）。

有些摄影师甚至会聆听他们的呼吸和心跳，并注意在呼吸和节拍之间进行拍摄，以获得最大的稳定性。

4.你的光圈太宽了

光圈的大小决定了景深，即图像的焦点有多少。这会直接影响照片的清晰度。

When a lens finds focus, it locks onto a specific distance known as the plane of focus.因此，如果您在 15 英尺处对焦，那么距相机 15 英尺远的所有物体都将具有最大清晰度，而该平面前面或后面的任何物体都将开始模糊。这种模糊效果的强度（即清晰度下降的速度）取决于光圈。

如果使用f/2.8等大光圈，景深会很浅。较长的焦距会放大这种效果，并且在拍摄特写拍摄对象时也会放大这种效果。因此，如果您使用长焦镜头，将光圈设置为 f/2.8，然后靠近拍摄，所得到的图像将只有一条锐利对焦的细条。 But if you use a small aperture such as f/11 or f/18, the depth of field will be larger, and more of the image will be sharp.

选择正确的光圈取决于您想要创建的图像类型。但如果您想让画面中的所有内容尽可能清晰，请尝试使用小光圈（由较大的 f 值产生，例如 f/11）。

请注意，小光圈会进入较少的光线，因此您需要使用较慢的快门速度进行补偿。查看此列表中的第一项和第二项！

另请记住，超窄光圈（例如 f/22）会因衍射而导致模糊，因此通常最好避免将光圈缩小到超过 f/16 左右。

5.你没有使用自动对焦

如今，相机变得非常复杂。所以让他们做他们擅长的事吧！相机在对焦方面表现出色，无论是静止物体还是运动物体。

自动对焦完美吗？不，在本文后面，我将多次讨论手动对焦何时真正有用。 But generally speaking, autofocus is the way to go.

基本上，如果您的相机设置为手动对焦，并且您没有充分的理由以这种方式拍摄，我建议您将其切换为自动对焦。我大部分时间都使用相机的自动对焦设置，您也应该如此！

也就是说，即使您设置了相机的自动对焦，如果您不使用正确的方法，您仍然可能会得到模糊的照片，正如我在下面解释的那样。

6. You're not focusing in the correct place

即使您使用完美的手持技术或坚如磐石的三脚架，如果您聚焦在错误的位置，您仍然会得到模糊的照片。

使用大光圈时，仔细对焦尤其重要（因为景深非常薄！）。焦点的轻微错误计算可能会使拍摄对象完全脱离焦平面，或者使拍摄对象的耳垂非常清晰而眼睛模糊。

摄影师经常将相机设置为自动 AF 区域模式，即告诉相机自动决定照片的哪一部分应该对焦。大多数时候，现代相机在这方面都做得很好，特别是当拍摄对象在画面中很突出时。然而，对于更复杂的构图，或者对于距离镜头非常近的拍摄对象，相机可能会感到困惑并尝试聚焦在错误的事物上。

如果您在拍摄时相机可能难以选择正确的对焦点，那么您需要手动指定对焦点。为此，请切换到单点 AF 区域模式。

当您通过取景器查看时，您应该会看到显示屏上排列着一系列小点或方块，如下所示：

这些是您的焦点，它们向您显示相机可以在画面中锁定焦点的位置。在单点自动对焦区域模式下，您可以使用相机的方向键选择这些点之一，相机将始终对焦于该点（并且仅对焦于该点）。

请注意，要告诉相机对焦，您通常会先半按快门按钮，然后再完全按下快门按钮进行拍摄。这种方法效果很好，但相机可能会过于敏感——如果您按得太轻，按钮可能会松开，并在您找到焦点后尝试重新对焦。如果按得太用力，您可能会在对焦准备好之前拍摄照片。 And if you take multiple pictures in succession, your camera may try to focus again before each shot.出于这些原因，您可能想尝试一下后退按钮对焦；它并不适合所有人，但它绝对可以带来很大的改变。

最后一点：

近年来，无反光镜相机增加了一些出色的针对特定拍摄对象的 AF 区域模式。在正确的情况下，这些可能比我上面提到的单点自动对焦设置更有效。例如，如果您正在拍摄人物并且您的相机提供了高质量的眼部自动对焦设置，那么您绝对应该尝试一下！

因此，请检查您的相机菜单，看看有哪些可用的自动对焦选项，并且不要害怕偏离我推荐的设置——当然，前提是您提前测试了这些模式！

7. You're using the incorrect autofocus mode

大多数相机提供三种主要的自动对焦模式。 You should be switching between these modes every time you're faced with a new shooting situation;否则，你一定会错过通常可以命中的投篮。

(Note that these AF modes are not the same as the AF-area modes I discussed above. AF-area modes specify where the camera should focus, while AF modes specify how the camera should focus. It's confusing, I know – but as long当你牢记这一区别时，你就会没事的。）

以下是三种自动对焦模式以及何时应该使用它们：

单次自动对焦（称为 AF-S 或单次 AF）会告诉您的相机在您半按快门按钮时锁定焦点，并保持该焦点直到释放快门按钮。因此，该模式应该用于静止的拍摄对象。在拍摄静止场景（例如风景、城市景观、建筑内部和静物布置）时，我经常使用相机的单次自动对焦。

连续自动对焦，称为 AF-C 或人工智能伺服自动对焦，旨在跟踪画面中的移动；当您半按快门按钮时，相机将获得焦点，但只要快门按钮保持部分按下状态，它就会不断地重新获得焦点。 It works best when your subject is in motion, and it's the mode I use when photographing birds in flight, wildlife running, and sports players in action.

最后，还有一种自动对焦模式，称为 AF-A 或 AI Focus AF。这可能是您相机上的默认设置。 It reads the scene and determines which of the first two modes it should use – but while automatic AF might sound convenient, it's pretty unpredictable, and it's not a mode that I ever use.请随意尝试一下，看看您的想法，但在单次自动对焦和连续自动对焦之间手动切换是我的方法，这也是我通常推荐给任何遇到自动对焦问题的人的方法。

8.你没有使用手动对焦

虽然我是自动对焦的大力倡导者，但在一个特定的时间手动对焦会派上用场：

当您的相机位于三脚架上时，您使用大光圈来获得非常浅的景深。

如果您想确保画面中最重要的部分清晰，请切换到手动对焦。然后使用 LCD 缩放功能将显示放大 5 倍或 10 倍。并对焦点进行微小调整，直到达到正确的效果。

You can also try manual focusing when shooting close-up subjects (eg, a flower petal) or when photographing landscapes in the darkness.

9. 镜头上或前面有垃圾

镜头上的大污迹会影响图像的清晰度。

如果您在镜头前放置廉价的塑料滤镜，也会降低图像质量。

So make sure your lens is clean. And make sure that all your filters are high quality.如果您总是使用紫外线滤镜拍摄，但照片总是模糊，请尝试在不使用滤镜的情况下拍摄几张照片，看看玻璃的质量是否会对您的图像产生负面影响。

10.你需要一个不同的镜头

初学者喜欢将模糊的图像归咎于他们的光学器件，尽管坏镜头很少是问题所在。

也就是说，镜片质量会产生影响，您偶尔会发现真正柔软的镜片。有些镜头可能中心清晰，但图像的角落和边缘变得模糊，或者在某些光圈处清晰，但在其他光圈处稍微模糊。每个镜头都有其独特的特征，这些特征可能对您正在从事的工作类型有用，也可能没有用。

It's also worth noting that each lens has a “ sweet spot ” – a certain aperture at which it performs best. This is usually in the middle of its aperture range, around f/8 or f/11.

固定焦距镜头通常最清晰，尽管携带两个或三个镜头而不是单个通用变焦镜头并不总是方便。

无论如何，如果您进行了我上面讨论的所有调整，并且您的图像仍然始终模糊，您可能需要考虑尝试不同的镜头。如果您不确定这是否是问题所在，一种选择是租一个镜头度过一个周末，看看是否会有所不同。 （或者，如果您附近有一家相机店，您也许可以进去尝试他们的一款新镜头。）

任何看过我作品的人都会告诉你，我痴迷于花卉摄影。带着我的相机趴在地上，仔细寻找美丽的拍摄对象，这是一件非常令人愉快的事情，甚至是放松的事情。另外，花卉也是如此平易近人的主题。 you can find them practically anywhere (as long as you look in the right season, that is!).

然而，如果说我在 14 多年的花卉摄影生涯中学到了一件事的话，那就是：为了拍出最好的花卉照片，你不能只是把相机对准并希望得到最好的结果。相反，您必须采用深思熟虑的方法，在最终按下快门按钮之前考虑几个不同的变量，例如相机设置、灯光和构图。

这就是我可以提供帮助的地方！在这篇文章中，我分享了我来之不易的拍摄美丽花朵的技巧、技巧和技巧。我将引导您了解入门所需的一切，从基本的装备和相机设置到我最喜欢的灯光和构图方法。

让我们开始吧！

推荐花卉摄影装备

你能只用便宜的相机拍摄出令人惊叹的花朵照片吗？是的 - 但如果您投资一些特定的设备，您会更轻松。 I'm not saying you should run out and buy thousands of dollars worth of gear, but some small upgrades can go a long way.

（如果有帮助的话，我最初的花卉摄影设置花费了大约 400 美元，包括我已经拥有的二手单反相机；换句话说，为了开始拍摄花卉，我花了大约 200 美元。如果你在装备选择上很小心，并且你愿意在二手市场购买设备，你也可以这样做。）

这里需要考虑几种类型的装备：相机、镜头和配件（例如闪光灯和三脚架）。让我们一一分析一下：

1. 相机

我的相机推荐很简单：拍摄花朵的最佳相机提供可互换镜头。 If you own a DSLR or a mirrorless camera, you're basically good to go, as these models all offer great flexibility in terms of settings and have a huge array of excellent lenses available.

您应该使用哪种特定相机？特别是如果你是初学者，这没什么关系。几乎所有可互换镜头无反光镜相机都可以拍摄出出色的图像质量，无论是针对专业人士还是消费者，甚至老式数码单反相机也能表现出色。 （值得记住的是，2020 年代超便宜且过时的东西在 2010 年代却是最先进的！）

我曾经建议花卉摄影师爱好者使用数码单反相机而不是无反光镜相机，仅仅是因为佳能、尼康和索尼的无反光镜镜头阵容还不是很发达。这仍然有一点道理——例如，如果您使用佳能数码单反相机，您可以找到更广泛的近焦镜头，而不是佳能无反光镜相机——但差异不再那么明显。

（另外，您始终可以使用适配器将 DSLR 镜头安装到无反光镜系统上。事实上，这就是我最近进行花卉摄影的方式：使用无反光镜相机和 DSLR 微距镜头。）

2. 镜头

Once you have an interchangeable lens camera, you'll need to pick the right lens.现在，我想强调的是：使用任何镜头，无论是微距还是非微距，广角还是长焦，都可以拍摄出好的花朵图像。我使用佳能 50mm f/1.8 镜头拍摄了一些最好的花朵图像。

The problem with more conventional lenses, however, is that they don't focus especially close.使用 50mm f/1.8 镜头，您也许能够拍摄相当大的花朵的全画幅肖像 - 但使用专门的近焦镜头，您可以做得更多。

基本上，镜头的放大倍率越高，您拥有的机会就越多。 You can make intimate and detailed images of flowers.您还可以尝试更抽象的摄影技术。

这就是为什么我一般推荐花卉摄影专用的微距镜头。这些镜头通常提供真人大小的放大倍率、锐利的图像和出色的散景（即背景模糊）。其中一些价格合理，我之前写过关于选择完美微距镜头的文章。

请记住，较短的微距镜头（40-60 毫米范围内）通常更便宜、更轻，但要获得超详细的照片，您需要非常靠近花朵 - 因此，您可能会发现自己挡住光线。 I started with a 60mm macro lens, and while it worked reasonably well, I did wish for a bit more reach at high magnifications. After a few years, I invested in a 90mm lens, and the extra working distance definitely helped, though it was far from critical. A few more years went by, and I decided to try shooting with a 150mm lens, but I wasn't a huge fan;镜头又长又笨重，我无法获得与较短型号相同的亲密视角。

无论如何，较长的微距镜头是否适合您取决于您​​的预算以及您想要拍摄的照片类型。如果你持观望态度，我可能会选择更短的微距镜头；这些型号在拍摄非微距拍摄对象时也很方便，因此即使几年后升级，您的微距镜头也可能不会浪费。

另一种选择是使用普通镜头（通常是长焦镜头）加上延长管。 Extension tubes are a cheap way of reducing your lens's minimum focusing distance, therefore allowing you to shoot at higher magnifications.延长管的主要缺点是灵活性。

当安装在相机和镜头之间时，延长管会大大缩短最大对焦距离，从而阻止您快速改变焦点。因此，安装了延长管后，您无法拍摄远处物体的图像；您只能拍摄几英尺内的拍摄对象。

进行廉价花卉摄影的第三种方法是使用自由镜头。 By detaching the lens and placing it in front of the camera body, you can increase magnification (while also generating some interesting effects).我经常使用我的佳能 50mm 镜头和旧的 DSLR 来完成此操作；由于传感器确实存在灰尘进入的风险，因此我不想使用我的主要设备。

3.人工照明

花卉摄影师通常喜欢使用人造光源（例如闪光灯或环形灯），尤其是那些经常在工作室工作的摄影师。

我已经使用和不使用闪光灯进行了拍摄，并且测试了环形灯，但说实话，我更喜欢在自然光下进行户外拍摄。 It's not as flexible as artificial light, but it keeps my setup from getting too bulky, and it simplifies my shooting process.

另外，人工照明的成本可能会有些高。不过，我要指出的是，在自然光不理想的情况下（例如，当您在明亮的正午阳光下拍摄时），闪光灯可能会很有用。当我进行室内花卉摄影时，我也喜欢使用专用的工作室闪光灯，但如果您确实喜欢在室内拍摄，那么您绝对可以在光线透过窗户的情况下拍出漂亮的照片！

4. Tripods

对于许多认真的花卉摄影师来说，三脚架是必需品。三脚架确实有真正的好处：即使在较暗的条件下，它也可以让您使用窄光圈（这有助于确保整朵花保持清晰）。

然而，对我来说，三脚架根本不值得。三脚架体积庞大，安装起来需要很长时间，尤其是当您在高放大倍率下工作时（花卉摄影师通常都是这样！）。我更喜欢手持带来的灵活性，以及​​它如何让我从各个不同的角度进行拍摄：平放在地上，从上面向下，等等。

也就是说，如果您希望在拍摄花朵时达到某些效果，您肯定会想要投资一个坚固的三脚架。我将在下一节中详细讨论这一点：

花卉摄影的理想相机设置

花卉摄影师通常追求两种外观之一：整个画面清晰（即深景深）或浅焦点。

The sharp-throughout-the-frame technique requires a very narrow aperture (often at f/16 or beyond, especially when you're shooting at high magnifications).这时候就需要三脚架了。

（为什么呢？因为窄光圈进入的光线非常少——所以要以 f/16 拍摄，你需要使用较长的快门速度来补偿。快门速度越长，相机抖动就越会导致你的花photos to blur!)

深景深花卉照片有时还需要一种称为焦点堆叠的特殊技术，以防止来自较高光圈的衍射。

然而，我个人更喜欢浅焦微距摄影。这不需要额外的设备，不需要闪光灯，也不需要三脚架。相反，您可以使用大光圈（在 f/2.8-f/7.1 范围内）来渲染花朵的一小部分焦点。图像的其余部分被模糊化，这可以产生独特且令人惊叹的效果。

如果您查看我在本文中包含的图像，您会发现它们中的大多数都使用这种浅焦点方法。我使用的光圈设置因镜头而异，但在进行此类特写花卉摄影时，我经常在 f/4 左右工作，以保持拍摄对象的一小部分锐利。 （这样，观看者的眼睛就有了清晰的定位点。）

Note that in both of the flower photography approaches I discuss above, it's the aperture , and not the shutter speed or ISO , that's important.光圈设置焦点窗口；我鼓励您从这里开始，然后选择快门速度和 ISO，以创造良好的整体曝光效果。

请记住，手持拍摄低于 1/100 秒左右的清晰照片是很困难的，而且当您以高放大倍率拍摄时，以 1/100 秒手持拍摄会存在风险，尤其是在您的相机和镜头不包含任何图像稳定技术的情况下。当光线真正开始变暗时，我只会将快门速度降低到 1/160 秒以下，在这种情况下，我总是拍摄大量额外的照片，希望其中一张能够相对清晰。

Before I move on, I want to mention three additional settings tips.

First, only raise the ISO if you absolutely have to. The higher your ISO, the more your files will be plagued by unsightly noise effects – so when possible, keep the ISO in the 100-200 range.

Second, in order to use the flexible settings approach I described above, you'll want to use Aperture Priority mode or Manual mode. I like Manual mode because it forces me to be aware of all my settings all the time – but Aperture Priority mode is a perfectly legitimate option, too!

How to use lighting to improve your flower photos

I am going to primarily discuss natural light for photographing flowers. That's not because artificial light in flower photography is useless, but because I think it's much more enjoyable to experiment with the light that's available.

My first piece of lighting advice is to shoot on overcast days. When the sky is cloudy, the light becomes diffused. The flower will be evenly lit, and the soft light will make colorful petals pop.

My second piece of lighting advice is to shoot in the morning or evening when the sunlight is golden . This prevents strong sunlight from falling on the flower and can generate some outstanding images.

I also like to shoot in the shade with the sun behind me, so that the bright sunlight is falling behind the flower (but not on it directly). One way to ensure this lighting is to find a flower that is in the shadow of a tree. Another is to cast the shadow yourself, by using your head, arm, or even your camera bag.

Enhancing your flower photos with powerful compositions

A final aspect of flower photography to consider is the composition. This may seem daunting for the beginner, but there are a few simple compositional guidelines that will help you take better flower photographs instantly:

Fill the frame with your subject

In flower photography, you rarely want to have a lot of empty space in your frame. More empty space means more opportunities for distraction, for confusion, and for loss of impact. So instead of leaving space around the flower, move in closer to fill the frame as much as you can.

The more colorful, the better

When photographing flowers, you often have a whole palette of colors right in front of you.利用它来发挥你的优势！

Put color in the background by placing another flower behind your main subject. Add color to the foreground by shooting through several other flowers.

Keep things clean

In flower photography (or any type of photography, really), it's important to have a point of emphasis (or a focal point). This can be the edge of a petal, the flower itself, the flower plus its environment, but regardless, you must ensure that the viewer's eye is drawn to this spot.

One of the easiest ways to guarantee a strong point of focus is simply to have little else but that point of focus. I hope this sounds simple, because it really, really is. Hence, before taking a photograph, rid your potential composition of all distracting elements. This includes out-of-focus stems, as well as bright colors or dark spots in the background that don't fit the image as a whole.

Think about simplicity .

This article was updated in March 2024 with contributions from Christina N Dickson and Jaymes Dempsey.

If you want to capture refined, pro-level portrait photos , then it pays to master some basic lighting patterns. Now, different patterns can have very different effects – loop lighting, for instance, looks fairly neutral, while split lighting is far more intense – and for photoshoots that require dramatic, glamour-type images, butterfly lighting is hard to beat.

Not only does the butterfly lighting pattern look amazing, but it's also surprisingly easy to achieve in the studio. You can get good results with a single light (and from there, you can always add different modifiers, reflectors, and fill lights for an array of cool looks). Bottom line: If you're a studio lighting beginner, the butterfly pattern is an outstanding place to start. And even if you're a more seasoned portrait photographer, mastering the butterfly technique will pay off in the long run.

In this article, I share everything you need to know for beautiful butterfly lighting setups, including:

  • When you should (and shouldn't) use butterfly lighting
  • My recommended butterfly lighting equipment
  • A step-by-step method to create a simple butterfly setup
  • Advanced methods of modifying your setup for even better results

So if you're ready to get started with this gorgeous lighting technique, then let's dive right in!

What is butterfly lighting?

Butterfly lighting, also known as glamour lighting and paramount lighting, is a basic portrait photography lighting pattern . It produces a characteristic butterfly-shaped shadow under the subject's nose, hence the butterfly moniker.

If you look at the example above, you'll also see strong shadows under the subject's lips, chin, and cheekbones. That's standard for butterfly lighting: the effect is dramatic , and the light does a great job of sculpting the subject's face to create a sense of three-dimensionality.

Note that butterfly lighting differs from loop lighting , where the nose shadow falls onto the subject's cheek, and Rembrandt lighting , where shadows create a triangle under one eye. Butterfly lighting is a form of direct lighting; the light source comes from directly in front of the subject for that powerful, dramatic look.

When should you use butterfly lighting?

The butterfly pattern, when done right, can look amazing – but it's important to recognize that such a dramatic, intense effect isn't ideal for every portrait scenario.

If you're doing fashion portraits or glamour shots, then butterfly lighting will serve you well. You'll be able to give your models the kind of sculpted lighting that often appears in fashion magazines. I also think that the pattern can work for formal portrait sessions, but you'll want to ensure that the light is relatively soft (by adding a strong diffuser) to prevent the shadows from being too heavy and noticeable.

However, because butterfly lighting tends to give the face a thinner, sharper look, and it also adds a touch of intensity and drama, I'd recommend avoiding it when doing photoshoots that require a more natural, artless look. For instance, I generally wouldn't try the butterfly technique when doing children's sessions, family sessions, and engagement sessions. Instead, I'd look to other portrait lighting patterns that make the subjects look good without drawing attention to themselves (such as loop lighting, mentioned above).

How to do butterfly lighting: the three-step process

Fortunately, not only does butterfly lighting look amazing in the right scenario, but it's also easy to achieve. You'll need a light of some sort; I recommend speedlights or studio strobes, though you can use a continuous light, too. And if you don't own an artificial light, window light is another option – it's not as easy to control, but as long as the sun isn't shining through directly, the illumination will be beautifully soft.

Assuming you're using an artificial light, you'll want a sturdy light stand. I'd also encourage you to have a reflector on hand, though it's not absolutely essential.

Step 1: Position the light directly in front of your subject

Butterfly lighting begins with your light pointed directly at your subject (so the light beams toward your subject's nose).

Set the light on a lighting stand, and make sure that it's pointed in a straight line toward the center of your subject. Then raise it up above your subject, keeping it tilted toward the subject's face until it reaches a 45-degree angle (or thereabouts).

You're free to fiddle with the height, but you'll need enough space to get your camera under the light, and you'll also need the light high enough to create a beautiful butterfly shadow. (The higher the light, the longer the shadow – so if you're looking for a more intense, dramatic effect, raise that light even higher!)

Take a test shot. You don't need to pay attention to the overall exposure; just make sure you have the right shadow shape. Then continue to the next step:

Step 2: Add in a reflector

At this point, you should have the basic butterfly look (simple, right?), but it generally pays to slightly decrease the intensity of the shadows under the subject's nose, chin, eyes, and face.

Therefore, I'd recommend adding a reflector under your subject's chin. The closer the reflector is to the subject, the softer the butterfly shadow will appear – so look through your viewfinder and do some test shots until you get the look you're after.

If you want even more control, you can use a second light instead of a reflector. Make sure the light is several stops weaker than the main light (after all, you don't want to cancel out the shadow completely, or worse, send it upward!).

Pro tip: Check the subject's eyes for a nice catchlight or two. If the main light or the reflector/fill light is positioned too high or low, you can lose the catchlight (which lends your portrait a sense of life ).

Also, remember: You need to fit your camera between the upper light and the lower reflector. Before you move ahead with your setup, make sure you can shoot comfortably from between the two items.

Step 3: Dial in your camera settings

Finally, you'll need to expose carefully for your shot. I'd suggest setting your camera to Manual mode, then dialing in your shutter speed , ISO , and aperture ahead of time.

Assuming you're using strobes, the shutter speed should be determined by your camera's maximum flash sync speed (generally around 1/160s or 1/200s). Pick an aperture based on the depth of field you'd like to achieve (for an all-black background, an aperture in the f/8 area should be fine – it'll keep the subject sharp from the tip of their nose to the back of their head).

Then dial in your camera's base ISO value (this is often ISO 100, but on certain cameras, it can be slightly different!). The lower the ISO, the less you'll need to worry about unpleasant noise speckles creeping into your files.

At this point, your images will likely be very poorly exposed, but that's to be expected. You'll need to rely on the flash power to adjust image brightness; consider using a handheld light meter to accurately gauge the proper exposure variables.

Don't be afraid to take multiple test shots, especially when starting out. Tethering can be a big help, and it's something that I always like to recommend to beginners, especially those working with strobes rather than continuous lights; it'll let you view your images on a large computer monitor so you know exactly what you're getting and what to tweak. (Sure, you can view your files on your camera's LCD, but in my experience, this just isn't good enough for evaluating subtle lighting effects; it's very easy to miss key details, such as too-dark shadows or missing catchlights.)

Modifying your butterfly lighting setup for the best results

While the basic butterfly lighting pattern is great, and it can definitely get you plenty of pro-level shots, it's always good to modify and enhance your setups for uniquely outstanding results.

Here are a few tips for more advanced butterfly lighting:

1. Add lighting modifiers

You can do butterfly lighting with a bare strobe or speedlight, but if you'd like to create more flattering results, I'd recommend adding a modifier to your light source. Bare light sources are very small, and small lights create harsher, hard-edged shadows that flatten the subject. That's why nearly all portrait photographers – myself included – work with modifiers, which go between the light source and the subject to soften the shadows.

Beauty dishes are a great place to start, as they soften the light while keeping it directional for that nice glamour look. If you're after an even softer, ethereal look, consider using a softbox rather than a beauty dish. The larger the softbox, the softer the light (so if softness is your thing, try a 6+ foot octabox)!

Modifiers can get somewhat expensive, but there are some great budget brands (like Neewer) that offer reasonable-quality softboxes, beauty dishes, and the like for around $40-100. Just make sure that you purchase modifiers that match your lights – different lights have different mounts, and if you're not careful, you'll end up with a softbox that doesn't fit!

(As an aside: Once you've done enough portrait shoots, and once you've mastered enough lighting patterns, you'll probably have a huge collection of modifiers lying around your house/studio. And yes, I'm speaking from experience这里！）

2. Move your light closer or farther from the subject

If your lighting isn't looking as hard or as soft as you'd like, you might be tempted to focus on the modifier you're using. Light too hard? Put a large softbox on it. Light too soft? Add a beauty dish instead.

But while modifiers are a useful way to handle light-quality problems, you can create harder and softer lighting effects another way, too:

By moving your light closer to your subject, or farther from your subject.

Once you've established the basic butterfly lighting pattern, if you move your light closer, the shadows will soften. And if you move your light farther away, the shadows will become harder and more contrasty.

It can be a neat little exercise to test this out yourself – just pop a modifier on a strobe, find a willing subject, set up your butterfly pattern, then take a series of images as you move the light source closer and farther away.

Just keep in mind that you can't just move your light and hope for the best; with each lighting adjustment, you'll need to change other elements of the shot – the light's power, the light's angle – to make sure you get a consistent result.

3. Add a background

If you're after an ultra-professional look, I'd suggest including a background in your shot – one that you light independently from the model.

You can hand paint your backdrops, you can use sheets of white paper, you can find naturally stunning backdrops, or you can buy large fabric and/or paper backdrops online.

Another option is to use a sheet of gray paper, then add in different background files using Photoshop.

In general, it's best to light your background independently of your main subject. So first aim to create a low-key image of your subject – where the background fades completely to black. Then put a light on the backdrop with enough power to create an artistic ring behind the subject.

(You may want to put the light directly behind the subject so that it evenly lights the background; alternatively, you can use two lights positioned just outside the frame on either side.)

4. Add a rim light

The best portraits tend to contain separation between the subject and the background. In other words, you can clearly see where the subject ends and the background begins.

That's where rim lighting comes in: It lights the edge of your subject so that there's a clear difference between the beautiful background and your stately subject.

Note that the rim light will simply add to your butterfly setup. You won't need to do any adjustments to the main pattern, and I'd recommend you achieve all the necessary butterfly elements before attempting a rim light.

Position your rim light behind your subject and off to the side, so it's sculpting your subject from the back. You can technically do this a second time – on the opposite side – but one rim light is generally enough.

Then take some test shots, experimenting with different rim light exposure values and positions. Ideally, you'll achieve a very slight rim along the back of your subject.

Capture some amazing portraits using butterfly lighting!

Butterfly lighting is a stunning portrait pattern – and it's super easy to achieve.

So follow the instructions from this article. Experiment with different lighting modifiers and positions. And have plenty of fun!

春天对于几乎所有类型的摄影来说都是一个美好的时光。有很多令人惊叹的主题和机会：户外肖像、盛开的花朵和发芽的树木的微距照片、春天的风景和小动物等等。

That said, if you're a beginner, or if you're just feeling a little uninspired after a long winter, you may be struggling to come up with the kind of spring photography ideas that get you excited to head out with your camera. And that's where this article comes in handy!

I've been excited about photographing in spring for as long as I can remember – I often spend the winter dreaming of spring photo opportunities – and below, I share 10 easy-to-follow ideas for some spring photoshoot fun.

You won't need to travel far to capture great spring photos, by the way. (Many of these ideas can be tackled in your backyard or at a local park!) You don't need sophisticated gear, either; I offer gear recommendations with each new idea, but you can capture most of these spring pictures with nothing but a cheap camera (or even a smartphone) and some good light.

Ready to enjoy the beauty of spring? Then let's dive right in!

1. Focus on the finer details

No matter what you photograph, capturing the details is always a good idea – and that's especially true when creating springtime compositions.

If you like to photograph nature , you can whip out that macro lens and capture some stunning shots of bluebells, daffodils, or cherry blossoms.

(I absolutely love to photograph the spring flowers, starting with the crocuses in late March/early April, followed by the tulips in late April and May! While I do generally like to use a macro lens for this type of photography, it's possible to get nice close-up shots of larger flowers, like tulips, with a standard 50mm lens or a smartphone camera. And if you can find a field of flowers, you can always have fun with wide-angle compositions that showcase the amazing colors and patterns…)

If nature photography isn't your thing, don't sweat it! Spring is a great time to get out and about, so if you prefer to photograph in cities or at festivals, you can still look for some nice detail shots.

In particular, aim to photograph:

  • Bokeh : Bokeh and detail photos go well together, plus it's easy to produce beautiful bokeh when shooting close up. Simply widen your lens's aperture as far as it can go, push your lens to its maximum magnification, then adjust your composition to include colors and/or lights in the background. You can create nice bokeh with any lens, but the effect does work best with macro lenses or prime lenses with a large maximum aperture. And the longer the lens's focal length, the easier it'll be to make the bokeh look smooth.
  • Patterns : Nature is full of nice patterns, so use this to your advantage. Flowers can repeat, making for a very nice macro shot. Or you can photograph petal patterns on the ground (once the petals have fallen). At spring festivals, produce is often laid out in patterns, which is ideal for photography.
  • Backgrounds : Photographers tend to focus on the main subject, but did you know that interesting backgrounds are an essential part of great photos? They're not hard to create, either. Simply adjust your composition until you get a clean, beautiful background effect – using a wide aperture will help! – and snap away. If you're not sure how to start, try shooting up at the sky on a clear day for a nice blue background, or aim down toward the grass for a green background.
  • Lighting : The best photographers know how to use the light for all sorts of interesting effects, and you can do the same! In fact, a great spring photography idea is to choose a subject, then capture ten images that vary only in their lighting. For instance, if you're shooting a flower, you can capture light shining through petals, sidelight dramatically illuminating the flower stem, backlight creating an interesting flare effect, and much more.

2. Explore the wider scene in your spring photography

When photographing spring beauties – such as flowers and plants – you may be tempted to get in close and stay there.

But while this will certainly get you some stunning shots, you can also capture beautiful photos by switching to a wide-angle lens and shooting the scene from afar. Flower beds, blossoming trees, and petal-strewn paths can make for some gorgeous landscape shots , after all!

顺便说一句，如果您想捕捉一些美丽的春天构图 - 特别是如果您想包括花朵 - 这里有一些建议：

  • 查看天气预报：这里我说的是天气预报和花期预报。天气预报可以确保您在光线好的时候进行拍摄，而开花预报可以让您在花期进行拍摄。
  • 构图为王：与所有风景摄影一样，良好的构图将为您带来最佳效果。 Aim to balance your spring shots with compositional techniques such as symmetry, the rule of thirds , and the rule of odds .还可以将引导线融入到照片中，以增添一点额外的活力。
  • 添加额外的背景信息：还记得我如何鼓励您使用广角镜头吗？尽可能广泛并包含一些背景信息。例如，在当地建筑旁拍摄一棵樱桃树，或者拍摄一个走过花瓣地的人。

3.尝试自由镜头

自由镜头是一种创造性的技术，可以让您调整镜头的焦平面，而无需花费数千美元购买移轴玻璃。您可以生成各种充满令人惊叹的模糊效果的原始结果。

这是其工作原理：

首先，确保您的相机已关闭。小心地将镜头从相机上拆下，然后将其放置在镜头座的正前方。 (You can hold your lens in your left hand while holding your camera with your right.)

重新打开相机，然后通过取景器查看。慢慢地前后倾斜镜头，观察焦点所在的场景区域如何根据镜头的位置而变化。

当您准备好拍照时，只需按下快门按钮即可！

自由拍摄需要大量的实验，你会得到很多失败的照片——但成功会让你觉得一切都是值得的。可以尝试的几种方法：

  • 将镜头拉近或远离镜头座以获得不同级别的放大倍率
  • 更改焦距（尽管 50mm 是一个很好的起点）
  • 故意在相机和镜头之间留出一些空间，以防止漏光

请注意，您可以使用自由镜头来捕捉许多不同主题的创意镜头。许多自由镜头专注于花卉和植物 - 正如我上面提到的，这始终是一个很好的春季照片主题 - 但您也可以拍摄有趣的肖像、风景等！

需要注意的是：自由镜头会将相机的传感器暴露于外界，并且会增加相机或镜头掉落的可能性。如果可能的话，我建议使用备用相机和便宜的镜头！ （我通常会用旧的数码单反相机和我的佳能50mm f/1.8 Prime镜头自由使用，尽管在我使用这些技术的所有时间里，我从未真正损坏过我的设备；

4.捕捉一些户外肖像

春天是肖像摄影的美好时光。您可以找到一些令人惊叹的自然背景，此外，您可以将有趣的花主题纳入春季照片中。

这是一些简单的春季拍摄想法：

  • 将主题与树木结合在一起：客户喜欢包括美丽自然背景的肖像。将您的对象放在树木或花朵的前面，然后使用大的光圈模糊背景。树木线可以为照片增加深度，而花朵将产生令人惊叹的背景颜色斑点。为了好的触摸，请您的模型握住一两朵花。
  • 坦率的春季摄影：随着天气的变暖，人们开始出去享受公园生活，您将有很多机会拍摄享受春天的人。您可以捕捉人们穿过花朵田地，人们在森林中远足，人们在草地上野餐等等。
  • 抓住自拍照：这可能不是那里最原始的春季照片想法，但是每个人都需要春季的新个人资料图片。因此，下次您有机会捕捉自拍照时（并确保在框架中包括一两朵花！）。

5.进行实验

春季摄影是一个广泛的主题，但是如果您花了一些时间浏览Instagram，您会发现大多数春季照片通常是一样的。

想摇动一点吗？打破那些实验技术，例如有意的摄像机运动，图像组合等。这只是我在春季创造创造力的几种最喜欢的方法：

  • Try light trails : Spring foliage often grows by the side of the road. Take a walk at night, bring a tripod, and shoot some car light trail photos.请确保在上下文中包括一些春季开花！
  • 拍摄折射：如果您还没有尝试过水晶球摄影，那么您会错过！水晶球很便宜，而且它们可以产生惊人的效果（请参见下面的镜头！）。
  • 故意拍摄动作模糊：谁说Blur必须不好？在大风天前出去，将相机放在三脚架上，然后使用缓慢的快门速度。如果您可以在Mid-Move中捕获植物和花朵，那么您将创建一些精美的抽象结果！

6.不要忘记春天的节日

我上面分享的大多数想法都涉及鲜花和植物 - 但是在春季节和宗教节日也有很多很棒的镜头可以捕捉。

用相机和几个镜头出发（我建议快速亮序和广角变焦）。从远处拥有有趣的拍摄对象（以捕捉整个活动的氛围）。然后靠近一些坦率的街头拍摄。

尝试用照片讲一个故事。活动发生了什么事？这是关于什么的？人们如何参与？

旨在留下一些小迷你系列，讲述节日的故事！

7.捕获轮廓

春季有更长的夜晚，这意味着您有更多时间在良好的光线下拍照（即使您在一周中工作很长时间！）。那么，为什么不用有趣的轮廓拍摄庆祝额外的春天呢？

找到一个愿意的主题，然后选择一个包括大量开放空间的位置。您想确保您可以撰写，以使您的主题与天空隔离；具有自然的高度点（例如巨石）可能是巨大的帮助。

等到一天晚上 - 天空中太阳低时 - 并将自己放置，以使太阳从您的主题后面传来。您不需要将阳光保存在框架中，而是确保受试者背后的区域非常明亮。

接下来，将镜头指向天空中最亮的部分，然后使用它来设置曝光。目的是在您的受试者急剧不足的同时正确暴露于天空。 It can be helpful to capture a couple of test shots as you refine your exposure (you can always use exposure compensation to brighten or darken the file, or you can switch to Manual mode and adjust your shutter speed).

Finally, set up a careful composition. As I mentioned above, you'll want an uncluttered backdrop, which is often easy to achieve by getting low to the ground or directing your subject to stand on something, like a rock or a low wall.

And take your shot! If all goes well, you'll end up with an amazing result, though I'd encourage you to do a bit of post-processing later to bring out the colors of the sky and ensure your subject is plenty dark.

8. Look for wildlife

Spring is full of life, and that includes migrating birds, baby mammals, and more! Spend some time out in your local park or nature preserve, and you're bound to find an animal or two to photograph. Even if you're not generally into wildlife photography , spring is a great time to get started; see if you can find an area with relatively tame animals, such as a park with lots of regular walkers.

For the best results, you'll want to use a telephoto lens. A 55-200mm kit lens is generally long enough for large, tame wildlife (such as geese), though 300mm, 400mm, and beyond is best if you want to capture small songbirds and distant mammals.

That said, you can get great shots by going wider and creating more environmental compositions that include both the animal and the surrounding habitat, so don't feel like a telephoto lens is absolutely necessary.

(And if you want to photograph birds and you don't mind putting in a bit of extra work, you can always set up feeders in your backyard along with a makeshift blind. Spend some time sitting in the blind with your lens poking out, and pretty soon, you'll have birds striking all sorts of interesting poses! I tried this a few years back, and after a few hours in my blind – which was really just a tent – I had hundreds of close-up photos of cardinals, chickadees, finches, and more.)

One quick wildlife photography tip: Patience is often rewarded. Don't simply walk by a subject, take a few snaps, and continue on your way; instead, if you have the time, wait with your lens trained on the animal until it strikes an interesting pose. This can be tough, especially since there's never a guarantee that something will happen, but when you do get lucky, the results are often spectacular.

9. Photograph street scenes in the rain

Spring is famous for its rainy days, but instead of staying inside, I encourage you to take advantage of the warmer temperatures and head outside with your camera. Go to the nearest city or town, and see if you can capture some moody, rain-soaked street shots .

Here, a 35mm or a 50mm prime lens is often best, though if all you have is a standard kit lens, that's okay, too. Look for interesting moments and interactions between people, and make sure you pay careful attention to the overall framing of your scenes. It's easy to lose track of all the elements in your street compositions, but it's important that you keep everything well organized even when the world looks chaotic!

If you're up for a challenge, you might even try heading out at twilight. You'll need a lens with a wide maximum aperture, but if you're willing to put in the work, you can capture shots that combine umbrellas, wet reflections, and bokeh!

I will add, however, that spring evenings can get pretty cold, especially when the rain is coming down, so don't forget to dress appropriately.

And if you're shooting in anything more than a light drizzle, it's a good idea to use a raincover for protection. These are basically just little plastic bags that fit around your setup and prevent water from damaging the electronics. After years of shooting in the rain, I always carry a few dedicated raincovers in my camera bag, but if you'd prefer to avoid spending extra money, you can always make your own raincover with a trash bag and a couple of rubber bands. (As an aside, I once made a raincover from two rubber bands and a bagel sleeve! It did a great job of protecting my telephoto lens from the precipitation, though I'll admit that it looked rather silly…)

10. Have some indoor still-life fun

In some parts of the world, spring – especially early spring – doesn't look much different from winter. If that's your experience, see if you can recreate that spring feeling indoors by capturing still-life shots that feature fruit and/or flowers!

Simply head to the store and pick up some pears, apples, cherries, or any other subject you find appealing. Cut flower bouquets can also look great, especially when combined with colorful vases.

Then set up a small studio area in your basement, paying careful attention to the surface you use to display your subjects. (I like to use an old wooden table that I picked up from an estate sale for cheap, but you can use pretty much anything: crates, benches, planks of wood, marble slabs, bricks, even the floor.)

You'll also want to think carefully about the background here. Plain walls are nice, but you'll want to ensure the colors don't clash with your subjects. Another option is to drape something dark behind your setup – I use a large black tablecloth – and go for a low-key look, where the background fades into darkness.

If you own flashes or strobes, you can experiment with different lighting setups, but if you'd prefer to use natural light, that's okay, too! Just position your still-life setup by a window (some form of side light is generally ideal here, as it'll give you a more three-dimensional effect).

And make sure you spend plenty of time adjusting your compositional elements. In still-life photography, even a slight change in the subject's position can dramatically alter the feel of the photo, so the more you can test out different arrangements, the better!

Spring photography ideas: final words

If it's spring in your part of the world, I hope you found at least a few of these ideas inspiring. I'll certainly be out and about this spring – photographing the flowers, the landscapes, the outdoor activities, and more.我希望能在那里看到你！

So take a few of these spring photoshoot ideas and have fun! Head out with your camera! Capture some spring photos! And enjoy the warm(ish) weather!

HDR techniques are a great way to maintain plenty of detail in both the highlights and shadows of your photos, especially when dealing with high-contrast scenes (eg, a landscape at sunset).

However, once you've captured several bracketed files in the field, you'll need to merge them in post-processing.

Now, there are a lot of plugins that you can use with Lightroom to create high-quality HDR photos, but the truth is that Lightroom's own HDR Merge feature does an excellent job. With HDR Merge, you can create HDR files right within Lightroom, and you won't have to pay for any plugins or extras.

In this article, I'll explain why I recommend Lightroom's HDR Merge feature for blending your files, and I'll share my step-by-step process for getting a great final image (using several of my own HDR landscape photoshoots as examples) 。

让我们进去！

Advantages to using Lightroom's built-in HDR Merge feature

If you talk to other photographers who use HDR techniques, you might find that everyone has different software preferences. Some use Photoshop, others swear by Luminar Neo's HDR Merge extension, and still others rely on dedicated HDR programs like Photomatix Pro.

But while all of the above options can certainly get the job done, there are several advantages to using Lightroom for your HDR conversions:

  1. You save money. Most HDR plug-ins are not free, and if you rely on a different editor or a dedicated HDR program for your workflow, you can expect to pay a significant fee. But if you already own a Lightroom subscription, the HDR Merge functionality is built in.
  2. Lightroom's HDR merge creates natural-looking HDR images. Not everybody will see this as an advantage, but Lightroom does a great job of avoiding garish, over-saturated HDR photos.
  3. You don't need a lot of bracketed images . In my experience, two are enough for a good result: one exposed at -2 stops, the other at +2 stops. (You can use more bracketed files if you want, and this is probably a good idea if you have a really contrasty scene – but in general, two should work well.)
  4. The final HDR image is saved as a DNG file. Not only is a DNG file smaller than a TIFF file, but you can process it in Lightroom the same way you process any other DNG or RAW file. The main difference is that the Exposure slider runs from -10 to + 10 stops, rather than the normal -4 to +4. There is also much more information in the file for Lightroom to work with when you make adjustments with the Shadows and Highlights sliders (as well as when applying targeted adjustments using Lightroom's masking tools).
  5. You can take bracketed sequences hand-held, and Lightroom will align them automatically. Lightroom's Auto Align option lets you work with several bracketed photos that don't feature identical framing. Having said that, I've found the best results do come from bracketed photos captured with a tripod-mounted camera!

How to combine bracketed photos using HDR Merge in Lightroom

Working with Lightroom's built-in HDR tool is extremely easy – so even if you're not an experienced photo editor, you shouldn't run into any problems! Just follow these instructions:

Start in Grid View in the Library module , and select the images you want to merge. Alternatively, you can select the images in the Develop module Filmstrip.

Right-click on your selected images, then select Photo Merge>;HDR . (You can also choose Photo>;Photo Merge>;HDR in the main menu.)

The HDR Merge Preview window should open, and you'll see Lightroom's preview of the HDR image. Note that it may take some time for the preview to load, especially if you've selected a lot of images for merging.

You may be surprised to see that there aren't many settings to adjust. This is deliberate – the aim is to let Lightroom produce a natural-looking HDR image, which you can then process in the Develop module to achieve your desired look. But you do have a few options:

The Auto Align and Auto Settings boxes will be ticked by default, and the Deghost Amount will be set to None . (If you change the settings, Lightroom remembers your last inputs, so always make sure you're using the right settings before continuing!)

What do these HDR Merge settings do?

Auto Align is useful if the camera moved between exposures, which generally happens when handholding. If this box is checked, Lightroom will work to line up your different images so the blended file looks natural.

And Auto Settings performs a similar function to the Auto settings in the Basic Panel of the Develop module.

I find HDR Merge works best with the Auto Align and Auto Settings boxes ticked (see below).还可以选择更改DEGHOST数量- 在这里，目标是防止因帧之间的主题运动引起的任何伪像（例如线条或模糊）。 If your scene was completely still, just leave the setting at None ; however, if there was movement from shot to shot, such as a tree waving in the wind or a person trotting across the landscape, you can set the Deghost Amount to Low , Medium , or High .

You can't zoom in to 100% in the HDR Merge Preview window, so you may only become aware of ghosting once you move on to the Develop module and zoom in to 1:1. If you notice ghosting at that stage, you can always go back and reprocess the images. And you can tick the Show Deghost Overlay box to reveal the areas where Lightroom has detected ghosting.

(How do you know which Deghost Amount is best? Honestly, you'll just need to use trial and error – it's different for each set of images.)

Once you're done tweaking the settings, go ahead and click the Merge button at the bottom. Lightroom will save the merged image as a DNG file with the suffix -HDR appended to the file name. It'll also take you back to the module where you started. From there, you can edit the image as normal in the Develop module.

This is the result of my HDR merge. I used two photos, bracketed one stop apart. That's not a lot of bracketing, but it was a cloudy day and what I wanted was a photo that captured detail in both the landscape and the sky. On a sunny day, the light is higher contrast, so you generally need to use images bracketed further apart.

You've merged your images – what now?

Your HDR file should be treated as a starting point in your processing. It's a new RAW file that you can then edit in the Develop module to achieve the desired effect.

In my case, I thought the merged photo was too light, so I darkened it in the Develop module. I also made some tonal adjustments and increased the Clarity . Here's the same image, but after those edits have been applied:

The screenshot below shows a comparison between the HDR image (right) and the same photo taken without any exposure compensation (left). As you can see, merging two exposures has allowed me to capture the details in the gray clouds.

Note: If after merging your files, you think the image has too much of an HDR feel, you can use the Basic Panel sliders or local adjustments to alter the tonal values. For example, you can increase Shadows or the Blacks setting to add contrast, so you don't have the “unnatural detail in every shadow” effect typical of overdone HDR.

Here's another example, this time with photos taken in the sun that have a much greater brightness range. The two photos were taken at +1 and -1 stops, respectively:

This is the result that Lightroom gave after the HDR merge process:

And this is how it looks after editing in the Develop module:

The differences are subtle; I just made the image a little darker and moved the Highlights slider to zero to bring out as much detail in the clouds as possible.

High-contrast examples

So far, I've shown you how Lightroom's HDR Merge handles files that encompass moderate tonal ranges. But what if the scene has a huge tonal range, forcing you to created three or more bracketed images?

This next example involves three photos with a total of seven stops difference in exposure. You probably won't need to make the exposure differences that drastic in your everyday shooting, but it's always interesting to try.

Here's the result:

The water looks different in each version of the photo, so I set the Deghost Amount to High . Note that the deghosted area (shown in red below) covers all of the water – when I compare the three original images, I can see that Lightroom has used the water from the first photo in the sequence, avoiding the ghosting that would be caused by merging three photos with a different level of water in each shot.

Can't find your new HDR file?

If you're not sure where to find the newly created HDR file, set Sort to File Name in the Grid View, and it will appear next to the first image in the sequence (but make sure you are in the folder of originals, not inside a collection).

It's best to carry out the HDR Merge process with files that haven't yet been edited in the Develop module, as Lightroom only retains some of your adjusted settings in the final file.

These are taken from one of your images and applied to the HDR file. They are listed below (all other settings are returned to their default):

  • Presence sliders
  • The Color Mixer panel
  • The Color Grading panel
  • The Detail panel
  • The Lens Corrections panel

Lightroom also requires access to the original photo files. It can't create an HDR image from Smart Previews alone.
